xD31kwsJM5o5Q55TaxEvDw.text: Hazev features a takeaway counter for those on the go, and proper dining room and bar in its east wing.  I'm personally not a fan of vegetarian and vegetable-leaning establishments, but there are a few meat options for those who require the death of animals at meal time.  Overall a well-kept, cozy yet stylish establishment outside the hustle and bustle of the Thompson Reuters plaza.

MgPCo4nvAeS5Szi1SGPN3Q.text: Absolutely brilliant. We've eaten here three times and every time the food and service have been great.

AJM42WTgj-eObqepJH068g.text: On a short term rotation in London, staying in an employer paid studio, close to the office.  Although the studio has cooking facilities and pots/pans, I have no desire to cook as it's a studio and can only imagine I will smell like food the next day.....walked passed this place as I was craving a nice, sit down dinner.  Had a glass of wine and the stuffed aubergine.  Delicious!  Seasoned nicely.  A little pricey but the food was delicious and fresh and in a nice atmosphere.

Ihm8oDw85VUxgHxjZPmOnA.text: Delicious Turkish food, nice outdoor seating at the quay, friendly service. Like most Turkish places, excellent choice of vegetarian dishes.

aukWHYwCFbFBi_wJWohrrg.text: This is a sold place to eat in the Canary Warf district.  The food is good and reasonably priced my wife and I really enjoyed it.  A definite winner.

hZ7mbHVA5RLuezgcya-aPA.text: To be blunt, the deli was full of savoury dishes that made us wish we had not already eaten and unusual non-alcoholic sweet drinks that kicked the virgin cocktails to the ground. We had tea to accompany our cake though. There were a lot of cakes to choose from and many of them newbies in my cake eating experience, hence it was a tough choice that cake decision. Ultimately we homed in on Hazev pie. See full review at wp.me/p5fONJ-km

0711zmSwt3fpTDakHfnoyw.text: This place is a weird collaboration between Tas (who I don't like) and Haz (who I do, but not that much).The food is merely ok, though the decor, atmosphere and service are pretty good and it feels very spacious. The portions are smaller than you'll find at the likes of Alounak or Sadaf in Bayswater who offer similar (ok Lebanese not Turkish) food on the grilled side, and Sofra has a better offering for the mezze side of things (but I am not a fan of mezze generally).It does make a nice change from the usual boring chain stuff around Canary Wharf though so if you work in the area it's well worth a visit.

SFySgWUVSXMw6nlD1Yg-cA.text: Nestled under an overhanging grey office building and looking out over the romantic (if slightly scummy) waters of Docklands is the newly opened Hazev Turkish restaurant.Decorated by someone with a serious fetish for wood carvings and curtains, it comes across as a kind of "formal christmas" vibe which means it will be interesting to see if that attracts punters during the summer months. Perhaps they'll take back the curtains then - which at one point billowed from what I thought was a wall and almost enveloped me to the amusement of my friends. It has only been open for a few days, it was already filling out with a small crowd of people but with so many tables free then there was no problems getting a window seat. My two work colleagues had joined me to curiously try this place out, especially rating it against the other nearby Turkish restaurant, Mez.Staff thronged the entrance way and we were efficiently scooted over to the aforementioned window seat and drink orders taken.We decided on one colleague ordering from the menu and the other two of us going for the set menu "choose a starter and a main for 9.99" deal.Then the formally attired waiter brought our drinks - and he had gotten mine wrong. Diet coke instead of my lemonade. I valiantly pointed this out to him with quivering lower lip and ... actually I didn't really care to be honest, so I told him of the mistake (how will he learn otherwise?) and then said I would just take the coke. If he had been bringing me a coke instead of a beer or wine then I might have been annoyed.Warm, soft and very tempting bread arrived with a small set of humus and about 8 olives. Not going overboard on the quantity there but then they brought some more with the meal and looking on the bill later on, it was free after all.After a few minutes, justifiable since they appeared to be actually cooking the food in an open kitchen area rather than just heating it up, our starters arrived. Menu-boy got a tasty looking veggie cheese on a mound of mushrooms thing (Hellim?), while us Setcourse-boys got an edible set of greens with garlic (Maydanoz Salatasi?). Damning with faint praise maybe but actually it was just as well prepared and set out as when I've had it in other Turkish places - interesting but not startling.Then the main course arrived... Menu-boy had... something (Mentar apparently). To be honest I was too busy tearing into my lamb shish.Wonderfully cooked and still nicely sizzling hot on the inside which shows it came straight from the grill rather than loitering under a heatlamp.  Gorgeous and slightly crispy on the outside, these big blocks of lamb were lovely. Served with cous-cous which was moist enough (dry cous-cous is a pet hate of mine) and a nice set of veggies.Finished up with some pistachio turkish delight cubes and left looking curiously at the nicely appointed bar area which we will have to try some evening after work.Despite the drink mix up, which is probably due to new staff, I liked this place. I may order off menu next time too...Matt

photos.caption: Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom

ZbtLisCm10a6LqYA5RPl6w.text: This was a bit of a disappointment in terms of food. I suppose I was expecting above average food after several of my acquaintances couldn't stop raving about it. Either that, or we didn't know what to order.The Somon Tava, or skewers of deep fried Salmon was an easy eat. It's a quick clean up of the pallete and the deep fried part is not too much of a bother.Between the three of us, two of us wanted to go with something 'light' - so we abandoned any lingering desire for lamb and decided to jump in for chicken. Bademli Tavuk, or chicken casserole with almonds, tomatoes and green peppers. It sounded like something that could never go wrong - seriously, what could you have done to a perfectly sound combination of unsuspecting ingredients? For starters, someone mistranslated the English. What came looking like shreded chicken and broad beans, was really almonds. It should have really read Almonds with chicken, garnished with roasted peppers and tomatoes. OK - maybe it's just me, but at least 30 percent of my plate was full of almonds. I can't imagine why you would let a bland meat be overpowered by such a strong textured, albeit mildly flavored, nut. This main even came well recommended by one of the waiters.The Tuna Sote, chunks of tuna in a cream sauce, was super fishy. That tuna needs to be cooked a lot more for continued inclusion with the sauce. Or something else? I was born with a fish in my mouth, and I would like to think I know fish. They don't come like that.All in all, it seems like very little work went into perfecting the recipes. Going by the sample, however unrepresentative, Hazev definitely needs some work done on modifying these recipes (not just fine tuning).Five stars for the lovely location by the waterfront though! :-) The waiters were friendly and helpful and service was quick and elegant.

BDhwsxLRjeQueDt3iUtdWA.text: Nothing too exciting in terms of food or atmosphere, but it is just tasty and hearty Turkish food. It has a wide selection of hot and cold meze dishes which are ideal for sharing. The vegetarian mushrooms with cheese main dish is my personal favourite. The place also has a cafe and a bar area so quite convenient for many occasions. The restaurant is quite big so service is not great (i.e. takes a bit of time to order/ get your food, etc), but staff is friendly and helpful.

RlOAIsZePNks6cDvK7TIaA.text: Good ambience, decent bar but average food. There is a lack of a clear identity on what kind of food they want to serve.

8bctHZxSAVXlfVVM8ruucg.text: Happened to stop here on 7/18 after trekking out to this area of London and glad I did. I have a few pints at some Karaoke spot in the area immediately before coming here as I was CRAVING falafel ...Arrived about 20 minutes before the kitchen closed, waiter was fast , very fast. Place was nice, clean and if I lived in London I would be a regular. I love that is on the water...

XHyfYNLCUAaIgGTbk_p4jw.text: Love London this time of year, with the Olympics down the road from here there's a subtle buzz in the air.This open planned restaurant with views over the docks & Canary Wharf was perfect for a summer's business lunch. It was busy as we got there 1.30pm but were seated strait away, menu consisted of cold & hot mezze type of dishes, mains of grilled meats & fish, with some decent looking pasta dishes.We nibbled on the complimentary olives & fresh bread with homous, for mains I had a mix grill accompanied with salad & cous cous, the meat was flavoursome & tender.Great spot for lunch will be back I'm in the area.

4AhOcthFGa_NFKzgqgie2Q.text: Hazev's deli is the Turkish version of Central Perk. Full of friendly, albeit quirky people (bankers... God love 'em), cosy chairs, mismatched tables... just one of those comfortable places where you don't mind settling in for a few hours. But instead of coffee shop cuisine, they offer amazing Turkish meze involving a pic'n'mix of three different selections and home baked bread for the same price as your daily coffee and muffin. Places this awesome this don't exist in the real world - thus having to leave central London and travel well beyond a 'healthy' commute to South Quay (a name that may or may not have also been the name of a far off galaxy in Battlecruiser Millennium's freeware version). But I must admit, Hazev was worth it. The food was, dare I say, out of this world.

IIK5LN2Go7Jy_wb9TGFXfw.text: My second attempt to this restaurant after a very dissapointing first.  This time I recognize most of the Turkish dish after my trip to istanbul. For starter, we ordered prawn in garlic, tomatoish sauce. Ordered the lamb shank and stuffed squid as main.  All good except the stuffed squid not the best, not as tasty as we thought. For dessert, we ordered milk rice pudding and kadayif with walnut (rather than pistachio) again very dissapointing, overly sweet, the cinnamon overpower the dessert and it doesn't taste good in general. Not sure if I have tasted the real thing that's why I have something to compare to but for sure there is room for improvement to bring the local taste to London. As for service, have to say it is very bad. We were guided to our table and after the main, basically we have to catch the attention of several waiters passing by us to bring us water, dessert menu and bill. It is quite annoying because we are sitting right at the place where it leads to the kitchen door. I will not strongly recommend this restaurant to my friends but I guess is a quick fix for Turkish food....

laz8dkMQGNPhurz8Gx_14Q.text: This is supposed to be a Turkish Restaurant, I was not impressed, the ambience was terrible and the food was best suited for an animal.  I dare say this was the worst supposed restaurant in the world, if you'd pardon the pun. I have complained to the authorities, however they're too busy Policing the Olympics.  Don't say I didn't warn you.Seriously though, this restaurant is no good.

eA4xRXl-ESsP1vCmFV7Z6g.text: The waiters here either don't eat the food or have very bad taste. The quality of the dishes are a bit hit and miss. Some tasty stuff and some stuff that is very marginalI has the lamb casserole which was quite good. The waiter recommended a candied chestnut dessert for me and a yogurt dish for another person. They were both terrible. The aubergine dessert was terrible- surprise!  The shredded pastry dessert was the only decent one of the lot. But if you don't want pastry or ice cream, don't have dessert.

lxT-wIOoTRuQ4d-e8QZCRg.text: Since my favorite Turkish restaurant in London closed down, I would have to say this place is the closest that it comes to Ozer so for me this is now The Best Turkish Restaurant in London - Beautiful Views, Delicious Food, nice clean white table cloth and sitting outside during summer is heavenly too!

Dj4UPx-mubx9rcNQGSaOgA.text: Went out for dinner for my birthday and was pleasantly surprised by the location as you can have a view of the river. Interior design was beautiful and the presentation overall was good. However, it was packed and service did take some time ( definitely book in advance especially for a Friday or Saturday). When the food came, it was delicious and they were courteous as it was delayed. The restaurant also has a cafe attached so you can just enjoy Turkish snacks and tea.

nuB4__y-FBMveOjmORDtVQ.text: I really liked Hazev, it was a great place to go for coffee and snacks, food was good, but the standout is definitely their desserts.Service left a lot to be desired but that could be said for many UK restaurants.I would recommend trying their:Baklava - melts in your mouth and so addictiveChocolate cake (I know, what's so special about chocolate cake, but this cake is to die for!)Turkish delights - definitely try these, very authentic

kR4_IJqSVWPRi2FTJU5hRw.text: I've been to this place twice now on team lunches and both times the food has been excellent! Situated at the bottom of Discovery Dock, this place has been drawing lots of attention and manages to keep the very large seating area fairly full during lunch. They also have a deli section which I haven't tried.I think they should call this place Tender instead because that's how they serve their meat! Creates a smile on your face that starts from your belly glowing with glee :)The only criticism is the staff. They do struggle during peak hours and I've noticed them drop crockery and cutlery many times.But definitely check this place out for good turkish food!

_dfOIjZOY2O_aLdwMtPVlQ.text: My team doesn't go out for work lunches much... too busy, nose to the grindstone, stealing from the poor to give to the rich, you know how it is. Nah, it's really cos we're just outside Canary Wharf, South Quay... where bankers go to die. Of hunger. Because that place is bleak, very little beyond builders' cafs and nearby Nandos. Except for Hazev of course!Matt. H's review of the main restaurant is right on the button, it is a bit stuffy and formal and not cheap. And with mediocre food. But the deli is a revelation. Way more chilled out with big tables and a relaxed vibe. They have a huge selection of savoury pastries, mini pizzas, quiches and a mezze selection that is divine. Very veggie friendly!They also have lots of traditional Turkish sweet treats. Hmmm baklava heaven! You can take out or eat in and it is as fabulous a spot as anywhere in central London.

wYFTthI3RRmP86_MfbW-Jg.text: fantastic Turkish / mediterranean food. Kabobs are to die for, i forget which one i had but i recall mixed plate was awesome. Dont miss their deserts. I usually hate baklava, but this one was just amazing.

OuJxDlqXnoaCRAK9TmOWYA.text: I used to like coming here but the past few times I have come the staff are rude. There is no sense of service or that you are welcome to dine here.I have been here many times in the past dressed from suited canary wharfer to casual weekender. I just give up with this place now. There are far better places.Food is ok but overpriced.

lPoOpDNBJXmvmuCo8dGsSA.text: If heaven is anything like the delicatessen at Hazev, then I might just have to start taking the whole Jesus thing more seriously.

gxsbno3IENM2lNMx4jO2TQ.text: This is a great Turkish restaurant located right beside the Thames river. The salad was very fresh with quite many unique and balanced herbs, the lamb dish was delicious food, we really enjoyed and a great addition to our trip in London.

WMW268OTdnV9KnWgMChvaQ.text: Other than döner kebaps in Berlin, this was my first shot at Turkish food. And the quality was much better! Ambience was very cool, and with an interesting eastern touch! The food was very flavorful and I was surprised how big the restaurant was. This place seems very popular. I would definitely come here again!  Definitely not my last time with authentic Turkish cuisine! Yum!

photos.caption: Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom

FB_QrE1Kt41uIfv-iAb-uA.text: An extremely flavorful meal! We got one of the mezze platters which included a huge variety of yummy things. Very vibrant colors, and a wide spectrum of textures and flavors. The baba ghanoush had a delicious roastiness, the hummus was creamy, and the tabbouleh was fresh. There were a few complex salads that I didn't know (one had lots of nuts) but were even better than the familiar favorites. A definite go if you're in the area. There is a deli on one side and a more formal sit down restaurant on the other, so you can easily get takeout if that's your vibe.

HjO5m-geFE9gBDIklEaXaQ.text: I love Turkish food. And this place brings the best in Turkish cuisine. The menu has a large variety of choices, vegetarian friendly. Again, we are big fans of restaurants that have super clean tablecloths. Big points for that!

DMbOmNnSsRwbc6VbP_c1oQ.text: Beautiful location. Right on the quay, this is a quite spacious Turkish resturant/ bar/ cafe in canary wharf. With this many purposes, Havez should be put down as a 'go-to' / last resort for any occasion. I certainly enjoyed my drink here, not too sure whether its a good thing, but its away from the hussle that you will find in this area. I mean I hate queuing for my drinks, I like to sit and chill with scenery and with the option of sitting inside and outside with comfortable seats, I like to be close to the station, and I like the option to either have a a drink, or quick sit down meal. Being a Turkish resturant is just a bonus for me. Service is good, and friendly, food is decent. And venue is big but has charm, with slight Turkish theme. Overall a good experience.

NSQR-GMI8TlLgpjfvs7Hvg.text: Just when I thought I found a Turkish restaurant that wasn't a Tas (the chain taking over London), turns out that this multi-function Turkish restaurant/bar/cafe is also part of Tas but going by a different name. Tried the deli food, though they were happy to order from the restaurant menu a tomato soup, as all they served in the deli was red lentil soup, which was very tasty. Tried an assortment of cold meze and it was generally good flavour and decent portions. Not overwhelmed by flavours here but the service is friendly, the ambience very chilled for a cafe-deli and its clean and fresh.They also sell Turkish oil, wine and sauces, snacks, cheese etc. Most with the Tas brand.

photos.caption: Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom. The deli/cafe part

ViZ__9v82ZMD6Ubkt5_coA.text: Excellent middle eastern food selection for vegetarian, meats and seafood. Desert are also impressive with different authentic varieties. Gluten free dishes are available and tasty as well. Nice quite ambience and soft music in the background. Superb fast service.

FzhEFvqnwgirw_QUJag0Hg.text: the 2 stars go for the staff that is really attentive. Sadly, the food was not commendable  but I put the blame on myself for the choice, since, as a turkish food passionate, I should have avoided Canary Wharf where I was not reasonably expected to find any good but pricey.

photos.caption: Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom

TFCrDAfBQT3mCe6on3nnhw.text: Nice location and decor.We had a selection of mixed starters , nice , the shish kebab red pepper was tasty and not at all like a vegetarian dish.For my mains I was very impressed with the hummus with lamb. a very different taste . Service was ok. A standard turkish restaurant

sFklqcUaSA8gZBBMD8oB6w.text: Came here for a leaving do - not many Turkish restaurants in the area so glad to have this restaurant near by.Inside is huge - and it's right next to the docs so many window tables get an amazing view. The place comes with bread and olives for free appetisers. Bread is good but they don't give you that much - you can always ask for more - it's free. The food came out super quick. I ordered the mix grill with sauce (forgot the Turkish name for it) and before I knew it the waiter was ready to served the dish to me. Overall it's not the best Turkish in London but it does provide a place to go to is you're craving Turkish in Canary Wharf. I'd go again if I'm in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom. Forgot the name - mixed grill with sauce

fMHRtJ_lgV6vLzmZrzHaPw.text: Probably not a good idea to visit this Turkish cafe if you're on a calorie controlled diet. However if you're looking for some very tasty home cooked cuisine, in the Canary Wharf area, this place is well worth a go. Recommend the hummus, spinach in yoghurt and any of the quiches.  Very friendly service too and reasonably priced.

photos.caption: Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom. Hazev side door

AlkiDWdXLEIJSqZQFe19wQ.text: This is a Turkish restaurant, located in Canary Wharf. It has a cafe on one side and a restaurant on the other. I tried their mixed grill, which was delicious. The atmosphere is more quiet and good for a romantic date. However, the service was quite slow, as the waiters are not very attentive.

photos.caption: Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom. Mixed grill with sauce

Q8TQM99tFvTs5ZjcnX214w.text: Everything in the Isle of Dogs is so weird, there's so much WATER and GLASS and DECKING. It's pretty beautiful actually but also you feel like something is about to go REALLY WRONG like a meteorite hitting. It would be a great set for a disaster-in-space movie to have its On Earth Denoument.Anyway...Hazev is not quite so dramatic. I don't know - it's nice? It's clean? It has Turkish Food? It has Turkish wine actually, which was exciting (although more for novelty value than absolute deliciousness. Not that I know anything about wine). It has quite a cool design - one end is a cafe & deli, one end is a bar. All of it is beautifully decorated although maybe its a tad impersonal (but that's in keeping with the style of the area).Food is standard and neither bad nor good. The dolma didn't taste freshly made, the kofte was decent (I should have had the sucuk but I was kind of on a date so was avoiding garlic although really why was I worried considering that person once kissed me after eating McDonalds: the horror).I've had too many liquorice allsorts and have overshared in this review. Must edit later.

HXxQMwCdzIQHA1KzOrO56A.text: Meh. I think that kinda sums this place up. I had an awesome eve but that was mostly thanks to the company and err the rather yummy bottle of malbec we ordered. Meanwhile the food is pretty average; we went for a selection of unpronounceable hot and cold starters to share, but you know a menu is lacking when the humus and bread is the most moreish thing you eat (mmm SO good though - just get 5 rounds of that!).The service was... confusing. Veering between over-attentively refilling our wine to spillage point and running out after us with the umbrella I'd left behind (yay), to being distracted by a conversation with a fellow waitress whilst taking our order and taking 15mins to bring the bill after we asked. Not ideal.Nice place to try if you're in the area - good veggie choice and there's pretty enough views of the river, but I don't feel the need to go back in a hurry.

i1zXj1NomjNu1r0xYj34DQ.text: My first time eating Turkish food and what a great introduction!  Ordered off a set group menu so had the opportunity of tasting many of the dishes they had to offer. For my main meal had aubergine and lamb which was delicious.  As we were a large group we had our own room which was very nice.

8IEjZFIAbHl2cDrJKVFHfg.text: I've been here on three separate occasions and thus figured it was time to give the Hazev a write up.  I do like the location as it does have plenty of indoor seating along with the entire bar which has an nice view of the wharf area.  In the better months, there is also outside seating.   The interior is nicely decorated, a little bit ecliptic but all in good taste.   The seating however is perhaps a bit tight, especially when at full capacity to which point this place is very loud.  Atmosphere rating = 4 starsI personally like the bar area as there is plenty of room to mill about and can accommodate large gatherings.   Even when the bar area is packed, the bartenders do a good job at keep the drinks flowing.   Bar rating = 4 starsWe got the fixed menu where they bring out a bunch of starters all of which is Turkish, thus made up of dishes designed to be mopped up with bread.   In my view the starters are really good and if not careful, they can end up being your meal due to overeating on the starters and being full when the main meal comes.   I like the varied textures and temperatures of the starters and they go along very well as you converse with your friends.  Starters rating = 5 starsFor the main meal, I've now tried two different types of lamb and one chicken.  The first lamb and chicken where variations of kabobs and in both cases I found the meat to be very dry and hugely disappointing.   The other lamb meal came with plenty of sauce and sitting on top of some mushy stuff which... at least is was not dry this time but I found it very bland.   Main meal rating = 1 starThe waiters were friendly and helpful in terms of giving better descriptions of the menu, but boy were they slow.  Now, I will admit the slow rate of which the food was coming to the table is partially due to the speed of the kitchen, but my God, there is no excuse for them to take 15 minutes to even start taking our drink orders... it was much quicker in going to the bar.   Even bringing out the starters they were very slow in getting all of them out.   When the main meal came, they also mixed up several of the orders as well.   Wait staff rating = 2

photos.caption: Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom. Starters
Photo of Hazev - London, United Kingdom

jHxTcwdZU115zRER4a3YmQ.text: Had the £10.95 dinner menu where you can choose 2 different dishes. I chose the lentil soup and the chicken shish. Before the food came, we had bread with hummus which was delicious. The lentil soup was pretty good. The chicken shish... that's a different story. The chicken was so dry!! What's up with dry chicken!Service was ok, the waitress wasn't  very pleasant.

qrm-pVt1kizakRI9OLIykA.text: Stumbled upon this wonderful place after ice skating and I must say it is really quaint considering it's right along the water. It was my first time at a Turkish restaurant and although the menu items were hard to pronounce, the food was fairly good! We ordered the falafel and our waitress also recommended the borek (set of 4 triangles filled with spinach and feta cheese - similar to samosas!). It was the perfect starter combo for 3 people along with the complimentary bread and olives. I'd say this is a great place for vegetarians as they have an amazing selection! Overall great service but it was a bit slow so you could see waiters/waitresses staring at their tables.

NHVb2MbeVtriRW7iSRjjTQ.text: We've just arrived from a week in Turkey, and stumbled on Hezev.It's a wonderful place. Amazing selection of food and coffee, everything tasted great, and we ate a great breakfast for under £18.Enjoy!

k3ukdnXI7o-naBCy9Tud6g.text: I've been to Hazev quite a few times as it's just round the corner from my work place. Food wise - I have tried more authentic Turkish dishes. There is some artificiality in the texture of the food and the way it's being served - however I can still call it quite tasty and I like the typical for Turkish restaurants 'dish sharing possibility'.The good thing according to me about this place is that it has three parts: the bar part, the main restaurant part and the coffee/ lunch part so it's good for any occasion. Although the entrance doors are separate for each part, there are doors inside in between the parts that enable you to change the location accordingly. I pass this place at least twice every day. Its location right by the path next to the Thames and its 'olive tree style' decorations with tiny lights on the trees outside make you feel want to 'pop in for a while' after a long day...
